section.title: Required or Optional Elements and Attributes
section.para: Information about "required" or "optional" elements and attributes can be found in the corresponding XSDs.

section.title: Predecessor(s)/Successor(s)
section.para: An Organizational Unit can have one or more predecessors which is to reflect through predecessor elements. Please use organizational-unit.xsd as parameter reference.

A predecessors relation is created and updated by pointing from a Organizational Unit to it predecessor. Each Organizational Unit has as virtual resource an XML representation of the backwards relation. This relation --from predecessors to the successor-- is automatically managed by the framework and is not directly alterable.

Different scenarios define predecessor relations. The kind of scenario is reflected through the attribute "form". Depending on predecessor form can an Organizational Unit have exactly one or multiple predecessors.
It is required to define the form of predecessor relation. Each form is coevally combined with a set of rules to prevent wrong relations.

Following types of predecessor relations are defined:
fusion Use "fusion" as from if the new Organizational Unit is founded by a fusion of it's predecessors. This means simultaneously that at least two predecessors has to exist. All predecessors should be closed (real Organizations usually not exists as separate Organization after a fusion and should therefore be in status closed).
replacement A "replacement" is to use if the Organizational Unit follows directly from one predecessor and the predecessor not exists any longer. Using replacement as predecessor form means also that only one predecessor relation can exists. The predecessor should have status closed.
splitting A "splitting" is to use if an Organizational Unit has more than one successor. The predecessor itself not longer exists. This form reflects a splitting of an Organizational Units into multiple new Organizational Units (e.g. each former department of an Organizational Unit without own id and representation is to defined as separate Organizational Unit). A predecessor relation with form "splitting" can only consist of one relation. The predecessor should have status closed.
spin-off A "spin-off" is to use if an department of an Organizational Unit is founded as new separate Organizational Unit and the predecessor is still active (with the rest of the departments). Only one predecessor relation with form "spin-off" is allowed.
affiliation A "affiliation" is to use if an independent Organizational Unit is going to be part of another already existing Organizational Unit. The predecessor, the affiliated Organizational Unit, not exists as separate Organization afterwards. Only one predecessor relation with form "affiliation" is allowed.
Predecessor elements are set or updated with an update of the whole Organizational Unit XML representation. A special method for this values is not supported.

The following snippet give an example how predecessors with form "fusion" are to define.
<predecessors> <predecessor form="fusion" xlink:href="/oum/organizational-unit/escidoc:123" /> <predecessor form="fusion" xlink:href="/oum/organizational-unit/escidoc:124" /> </predecessors>
